author: cole.vt
title: Project Catalyst Closing Made Easy
description: Divide between funded proposal, and output of team. In 7 funds with 575 projects funded only 43 have submitted a Catalyst closing report.

f6_assessments.q0: As the Challenge setting calls for better ways to evaluate funded proposals and improve auditability, a proposal around Closing and end-of-project reports is an excellent match. Although it does not address current abuses of the system such as individual proposers submitting dozens of proposals and hoping "to get lucky" or astronomical hourly rates hidden deep inside wordy proposals, to just name two, it would in the long run create a culture based on track record. Adding granularity and scoring milestones and partial targets are possible ways to expand on a Closing report, but as a starting point I fully agree with the proposers that this is impactful and important. Given the diversity and broad scope of Project Catalyst, including an equally broad range of measures, from smart contracts created and certified to social media metrics, shows that the proposers understand the complexities they are dealing with and this is a well-crafted proposal to help the brief of the challenge making progress.
f6_assessments.q1:
A broad alliance of the individual proposers, some of whom are veterans of the Catalyst process and impact entrepreneurship, together with Cardano for Climate and Sustainable ADA, creates in my view a powerful group of stakeholders to make this proposal a success. The websites already created look professional and existing social media traction of the project's partners are supporting the claim that this can be made into a success.
The project has an ambitious timeline but would have benefited from breaking it down - although there are phases all 50 proposals to be reviewed initially are lumped together. This is mitigated by the use of Gitbook, which may help in communicating progress and getting feedback necessary for successful completion and closing reporting on enough proposals.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal is supported by KPIs and a timeline, and auditing of progress and success will be possible in my opinion as the target to assess 50 projects is clear to understand and carry out. More information on selection criteria would have been good, highlighting how the team would deal with reluctant cooperation or false information provided. Given that this proposal sits in the Improve Auditability challenge, paying more attention to its own auditability and splitting the 50 closing reports / videos / reviews into sub-projects with check-ins after, for example, 10 trial videos, would have been beneficial for the credibility.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal puts forth an idea that, if orchestrated well, could set a new standard for Catalyst proposals and auditability. Systematizing the finalization of a funded proposal through a form for stand-alone video-recorded presentations could prove useful to both dedicated community members and outsiders interested in joining. It could either demonstrating impact or a process for community accountability; both very useful. As such this proposal definitely addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: The experience and documented accomplishments of this team is encouraging. To emphasize their experience they presented a video documenting the finalization of their own proposal, simultaneously showing both what they've accomplished for Catalyst already and how their new proposal will work. There is reason to have high confidence in this team and their plan.
f6_assessments.q2:
One area where there is room for improvement is that, in this plan as laid out, it's easy to conflate whether they are auditing a collection of proposals or providing a system for proposers to present the final versions of their proposals. 

It's evident with careful reading that the proposal is indeed for both, but this needs to be detailed more clearly to avoid confusion. Indeed, it would be nice if KPIs included closer attention to efforts to systematize this approach in the Catalyst system. Any progress on this front, especially with regards to the submissionform, should be reported alongside KPIs. Indeed, long-term, this may be the most important thing.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal outlines the problem of lack of closing reports submitted by the projects that have delivered what they have promised. This problem brings confusion on which funded proposals are done and which should be followed further. 
The solution of the proposal is to create a quick process to help proposers create and submit the closing reports.
This solution effectively addresses the problem and brings more clarity on which projects had delivered what they have promised, which aligns with the objectives of the challenge.
I agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal has a very good actionable plan which is laid out in detail. There is a timeline attached to the plan with a week or two lee way, which is reasonable. 
The budget is not very well described. It has been looked from the perspective of ROI, not from the standpoint of where are the money going.
The team is  well described and presented and very experienced with high visibility in the catalyst community.
I strongly agree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposer suggests that trough a gitbook page where the team will publish all their work the proposal will be auditable. The success KPIs are with a concrete number, so the success of the project will be easily measurable. However the progress of the project due to the lack of milestones with numbers and strict timeline is harder to audit. 
I agree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is a good idea, because it will help solve the issue that less than 10% of the funded projects are delivering a closing report. This proposal helps proposers to deliver such a report more easily, in a transparent and efficient way.
f6_assessments.q1: This team has completed several funded proposals. The goals seem realistic, taking into account past experiences.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal outlines a clear plan divided into 3 phases for the implementation with a reasonable time horizon.
There are a number of quantative KPIs described that measure the success of this project which can be easily evaluated, 
but evaluation of the quality of the closing reports is lacking. This will be more difficult to evaluate, 
but should also be a KPI in my opinion. This could perhaps be done by letting community users vote/review resulting closing reports.
A KPI could then be the rating for the presentation of the content of the closing report.

f6_assessments.q0:
There definitely is a significant, perhaps silent, problem regarding Catalyst funding. Extensive resources are being thrown at the initial phases of the projects (drafting proposals, comments from the community, assessments, veteran assessments, voting). However resources utilized after the projects have begun fail in comparison, and little is known by the community on how those projects have performed. The proposer states (no way for me to verify that only 50 of the 1000+ projects funded through project Catalyst have properly closed out their project. Terrible news if this is indeed the case. 

Now, the solution proposed is to allow a maximum of 50 current non-closed projects to fill out our form and inquiry to have their project closing report done for them by the team behind this proposal. So it would function in a way as a test subsidy for previous funded projects and help them to wrap up the project. 

It is a laudable and practical proposal to a major pain point, however I´d like to add a few worries. Firstly, it might introduce moral hazard amongst future proposers knowing that even if they don’t deliver on project closing, somebody might be there to bail them out. Secondly, this proposal would increase costs borne by the community for already funded proposals and perhaps throw money into an already money sink. Not a bright future I might say.

But again I do not see simple solutions to this problem.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team behind the project comprises three persons, with experience in several areas: a research focused member, a recent economics delegate and a social entrepreneur. Quite a balanced mix of skills to carry out such an experiment. 

Budget wise they would spend the 15k USD on only the first 50 projects that join in, meaning roughly 300 USD/project. Is it a lot? Is it just peanuts? I am not sure. 

The project would take around 4 months to roll out. An initial stage would focus on on-boarding teams that haven’t closed their projects properly and building presentation templates. Second stage would allow current non-closed projects to fill out a form and ask to have their project closing report done for them. On a personal note I find this stage extremely challenging to be able to close a report for under 300 USD/project. Phase three would encompass macro reporting and documenting the entire process.
f6_assessments.q2:
Being a project focused on closing other projects I can imagine that they will save 300 USD for their own closing. :)

Jokes aside, they promise an open-source project and one can only expect that transparency towards the community will be not only good, but perhaps a solid practice for the future and a very good window into the messy work of closing down projects and ensuring sufficient transparency from their side.

f6_assessments.q0:
The problem statement is really true and bring numbers to certify it exisits. Closing project is usually a neglected part in project management, even though it is so imporant. It allows to completely audit process, check lessons learned, update documents and free up resources. The solution, to have make the process easier, is good and does address the problem and challenge, as projects who follow this will more easily be audited. I apreciate having a marketing strategy to share this already considered here.
The main issue I see with this proposal is that it is not clear what will be this proposer responsability and what will responsability of the team closing the project. I understood templates will be provided, but who will fill them in? who would edit the video? It is a bit confusing here. Maybe a diagram describing the whole process with roles and resposabilities would help.
Moreover, it would be important to explain how these templates would be created and validtaed with the community.
f6_assessments.q1:
The plan is well strucutred, time-framed, with deliverables and description of each phase. I just wonder if the acitivty of creating the templates would be iterative with the community or with selected key stakeholders/potential users.


There's a budget breakdown by number of finalized projects but it is not clear how they got to $300 each. some rationale in this number could be provided (is it based on the number of hours worked?)

Fianlly, regarding the team, there are 3 people commited already and with good Cardano experience, which seems enough for this project. There are linkedin links to validate provided information of each proposer.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposed updated summary with the information on the progress can definetely help to audit this project. The kpis are good and most of them have targets already,which is good. It is mentioned, however, that the success metrics will depend on each challenge. Maybe some examples could be brought here (I understand that bring it for each challenge would be too much for a proposal).

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is directly in line with the challenge setting by tackling the challenge via solving the problem caused by proposers not closing out their proposals. As the proposers mentioned, only 50 or so of the 1000+ projects have been closed out, so it is incredibly difficult in the current landscape for the community to audit the success of proposals. As a member of the community, I can verify that I have not actually seen a closed out proposal, which indicates that this is a big problem that does need to be solved. By providing a simplified template for proposers, this project will help streamline the closing out process for many proposers whose time is very important. The team behind this project will then take information provided by the funded proposers and create a summary report slidedeck/video that will be sent to IOHK where it can then be sent out to the community. I see this proposal addressing the issues stated in the challenge setting because it will lead to more proposals getting audited. If the closing information of the proposals are widely available in a standardized format, more members of the cardano community can audit past proposals. (score given: 5)
f6_assessments.q1: Given the information provided, I believe that this proposal will be highly successful, with the only exception potentially being # of willing participants. The proposers mentioned that there could be a lack of proposers who are interested in using this service, but they addressed the problem by stating how they would promote the proposals they create reports for, which is an incentive for proposers to use the service. Combined, the proposers have all the necessary experience to make this project a success. For example, they have experience with blockchain technology and education (just to name a few of their experiences). There are also partnerships with SustainableADA and Cardano4Climate, which gives me confidence that they are in touch with the right groups to make this proposal happen. The proposers also listed out a very thorough roadmap that includes multiple phases. In the first phase, they will create the templates and get all the background preparation completed (2 weeks-month). In the second phase, they will get teams to submit their information on the form to get a report summary made of their proposal (2-3 weeks). Lastly, the proposers will spend about 2 months working on putting the summaries together and getting them published on a gitbook. The budget for this proposal seems very reasonable and is broken down on a per proposal report made basis. I do not have experience creating summary reports, but I think that the funds requested seem reasonable given the scope of the proposal. (score given: 5)
f6_assessments.q2: Given the information provided, I think that this proposal is highly auditable. The proposers have listed that their progress will be regularly updated through a summary. Their work will be published on gitbook, so the community can access their work and see if the proposal is being completed. Thus, not only will the community be able to audit past proposals, but they will also be able to audit this proposal while doing so for others. The proposers also listed some good KPIs, such as 50 proposals audited and social media metrics. Additionally, the closing reports themselves and their ability to convey whether a proposal was successful or not is another indicator of the success of this proposal. (score given: 5)

f6_assessments.q0: The idea of this project is simple but effective.  The proposer will help 50 other project build their close out reports (including videos) and most importantly will provide an open source 'dummies guide' on how other projects can do this themselves. This align perfectly with the challenges in terms of providing and efficient, consistent, scalable solution that can be used by anyone around the globe. It definitely ticks the Return on intention box (ie meets the challenge brief)
f6_assessments.q1: The ability of this team to deliver is high as evidenced by the videos attached to the proposals. Having spent several years producing and editing videos i appreciate the work that goes into the production and how difficult it was to get to a point where i could produce a quality product. Based on this experiment the timelines and milestone highlighted are sensible and logically structured. The budget is broken down by phase and at $300 per video/report is significantly lower than the market rate (in UK and US).  The only risk i forsee is one of capacity in the proposal team, they all look like they have their hand full so it would have been good to identify named resources to deliver each of the phases in the plan, that would have provided ultimate comfort to the community that the delivery will be taken seriously and delivered to a high standard (not saying it won't anyway).
f6_assessments.q2: The milestones and KPI are simple to understand and measure (50 close-out packages in 4 months) all presented via a Gitbook, plus a do-it-yourself guide for others to use in the same timeframe. Simple and clear.
